Award.AwardTitle: Student Travel Support for Attending 2015 ACM Conference on Computer and Communications Security

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The annual ACM CCS conference is a leading international forum for computer and communications security researchers, practitioners, developers, and users to explore cutting-edge ideas and results, and to exchange techniques, tools, and experiences. ACM CCS is the flagship event of the ACM Special Interest Group of Security, Audit and Control (SIGSAC). Its acceptance rate is around 15-20%, which makes it a highly selective conference.

This grant provides support for 32 students to attend ACM CCS and associated workshops. Preference will be given to undergraduate students participating in the poster session, and students with papers in the conference or associated workshops who do not have other sources of support. Participation by women and underrepresented groups will also be encouraged.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to partially support the travel expenses of selected student attendees to the 22nd Annual ACM Conference on Computer and Communications Security (CCS 2015) October 12-16 2015, Denver, CO. The annual conference, CCS, is often considered the most presitigious research conference in computer security.

The CCS 2015 Student Travel Grant Committee was chaired by Dr. Hasan Takabi  of University of North Texas and Dr. Indrakshi Ray of Colorado State University. We received 85 applicants from 20 different countries (in no particular order, USA, Canada, Germany, Italy, China, Brazil, Albania, Iran, Korea, India, Nepal, Turkey, Morocco, Thailand, Israel, France, Switzerland, Russia, Greece and Pakistan) of which 9 applications were submitted by female students.  One of the top priorities was to support the female applicants. 

For this NSF travel award, the committee selected the top 29 applicants who were from universities in the USA, including 5 female applicants, and supported their travel to the conference. Awards were provided at three different levels in the form of partial reimbursements for travel expenses - $1000, $675, and $500 - depending on their level of participation (conference author, conference attendee, workshop author/attendee, volunteer).  Of the 29 awardees, 25 were Ph.D. students, 2 MS students and 2 BS students). 1 more student was awarded but could not participate and so finally did not receive the award. This has resulted in a balance of $1,000.

We additionally selected 21 more students for awards who were not students at US universities. They were supported through other sponsorship that the PI was  able to obtain. This included one more female Ph.D. student applicant.
